div.head:
RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE PRELIMINARY COMMITTEE APPPOINTED
BY THE INTERNATIONAL CONGRESS AT THE HAGUE OF 9TH
AUGUST, 1907, TO PROPOSE ARRANGEMENTS FOR ORGANISING
THE SUBJECT RACES JOINT COMMITTEE ON A PERMANENT AND
EFFECTIVE INTERNATIONAL BASIS

list.item:
That this Committee be called The International
Subject Races Committee.

THAT the purpose of the Committee shall be to pro-
vide opportunities for cooperation between the
promoters and supporters of organisations favour-
able to the protection of the rights, and advance-
ment of the interests, of subject races and nation-
alities, whaterver their grade of civilisation.

THAT its intention being to assist the organisations
represented on it in securing unity and harmony of
action without in any way hampering their indepen-
dence, the Committee shal neither usurp the func-
tions nor interfere in the management of those
organisations nor be responsible for any action they
may take on their own responsibility.

That in advocating the cause of any subject nation-
ality the Committee shall maintain a strict neutral-
ity between any sections into which the national
party may be divided.

THAT the head-quarters of the Joint Committee
shall, at present, be in London, and its duties
shall include: -
(a) Such efforts as it can make towards the for-
mation of allied Commitees, in other centres.
(b) Such assistance as it can give in arousing
public interest in the objects aimed at and
the work done by any or all of the organisa-
tions associated with it and by communcations
to the Press, by meetings and lectures, and by
other methods which members may suggest and
the Committee approve.
(c) The arrangement, if possible, of an Interna-
tional Congress in each year, generally in one
of the European capitals, at which delegates
from the different countreis may confer with
one another, and agree to take common action.

THAT allied Committees being left to arrange their
own details of organisations, the Central Committee
shall be composed of delegates from the several
organisations represented upon it, not more than
three delegates being appointed by each organisa-
tion, and the Committee shall have power to co-opt
in certain cases, individuals not members of the
organisations represented. Such co-opted members
not to exceed one-fourth of the Committee at the
time of co-optation.

THAT the Joint Committee may appoint an Executive
or Sub-Committees, and shall elect for its first year,
a Chairman, an Honorary Secretary, and a Treasurer,
or other officers.

THAT each organisation represented on the Joint
Committee shall contribute not less than £2. per
annum owards its funds, the amounts being due at
the time of joining and annually afterwards from
that date; and that general subscribers of 10s.
or upwards, shall be entitled to copies of all its
publications and to the right of entrance to its
International Congresses or other publich gatherings,
but not of voting.
